base sizes for miniatures and you can finish them really any way you want so
I'll show you how to do a fantasy version and a sci-fi version in this
video so let's get to the table so the rules for these are pretty basic sides
that meat will always be 4 inches wide with 3/4 of an inch on each side used up
for the embankment or wall so do a fantasy themed one in a few but for
example let's make a corner for a futuristic battle line measure out a
4-inch square from chipboard and draw on some lines
3/4 of an inch in word to show where the walls will go for 28 millimeter scale I
like a 3/4 inch tall wall so that the soldiers can see over it so I cut some
chipboard to be that tall then take some toothpicks and chop off the pointy ends
and hot glue them along a strip at a regular interval I'm using about one
every inch and then hot glue another strip of chipboard over that to sandwich
it all together this also gives you a nice channel on the underside to absorb
the bead of hot glue as you attach the wall to the base it's an extremely
strong connection and here it is with the small interior
corner walls done up as well now take some cross stitching mesh sometimes
referred to as granny grading and cut out a piece to insert I apply it using
white PVA glue like Elmer's when you apply it keep the nozzle in contact with
the base to force the glue to spread out instead of making a bead or just use
your finger and spread it out smoothly after you apply it I like white glue for
this because hot glue beads up and creates a texture that you don't want
here's a few other example shapes all based off a four inch square but suppose
you want to make a 45-degree corner here's how first measure four inches
along a clean straight edge then take a protractor stake it at the beginning of
the line and Mark a 45-degree angle connect that mark with the point you
just used and then along this newly drawn line measure out four inches again
finally connect the two remaining marks
together to finish the triangle this is a perfect 45 degree wedge
so then I flock the outside with pebbles and sand as we've done many times before

so based the trench itself in black then apply another base of gunmetal but when
you do the mesh use the brush at an extreme angle almost as if you were dry
brushing in order to ensure that you don't get any silver below the mesh then
I applied a black wash to all the gunmetal just a mix of mostly water and
a touch of black paint and then dry brush some shimmering silver on all the
metal to really sell it as metal for the outside I'm using the same scheme is
